details.title: An Inference Methodology for Life Tests With Complete Samples or Type-II Right Censoring
details.standardTitle: An Inference Methodology for Life Tests With Complete Samples or Type-II Right Censoring

p: Andrew G. Glen is a Professor in the Department of Mathematical Sciences at the United States Military Academy in West Point, NY. He received his B.S. (1984) in Mathematics, and Computer Science (concentrations) from the United States Military Academy; and his M.S. (1995), and Ph.D. (1998) in Operations Research from The College of William & Mary. His research interests are in computational probability, an emerging field that uses computer algebra systems to expand the set of analytic solutions in probability and statistics. A professional Army officer of over 25 years, he has served in line units, and has been deployed on numerous operations before being assigned to the permanent military faculty at West Point.

Bobbie L. Foote is a Professor Emeritus from both the United States Military Academy, and the University of Oklahoma, serving more that 40 years in academia. He received his B.S., and M.S. in Mathematics from The University of Oklahoma. Also from that school he receive a Ph.D. in General Industrial Engineering, and a minor in History of Science. He has taught undergraduate, and graduate courses in 11 different areas of Systems Engineering, and Mathematics. He is a fellow of The Institute of Industrial Engineers, has received the civilian Medal of Excellence from the United States Army, and was two time Director of the University of Oklahoma School of Industrial Engineering where he was a 30 year faculty member. He won the Merrick Foundation Award for the development of The Senior Projects course. He is now retired and enjoying grandchildren. He has a new career defending the Christian faith with his knowledge of Mathematics, Engineering, Physics, History, and Biblical scholarship. He recently lectured on this subject at Patrick Henry College.

details.abstract: We present a methodology for gaining statistical inference during the actual conduct of a life test experiment that can reduce time on test and cost. The method relies on properties of conditional order statistic distributions to convert censored data into i.i.d. uniform variates. A secondary result presents a new test for uniformity based on the convolution of these i.i.d. uniform random variables that is higher in power than the benchmark Anderson-Darling statistic in certain cases.

context.text: Recently, Wu, Tsai, & Ouyang [18] extended the research of Balasooriya [1] to obtain statistical inference from censored samples.

sampling plans for the exponential distribution

context.text: Testing for uniformity of a sample has many applications, some of which are explained in Chapter 8 of D'Agostino & Stephens [2].
David [3] discusses the Markov nature of conditional order statistics.

In his work on order statistics, David [3], pg. 20, explains two useful properties that we employ: that order statistics form a Markov chain, in that for \$r<s\$, and that deriving the distribution of these order statistics is made simpler with truncated distributions.
Also note that we find the conditional order statistic using the truncation of the parent distribution method outlined by David [3].

references.text: H. A. David, Order Statistics, 1981, John Wiley and Sons.

We implement the new method, and new statistic in APPL (Drew et al., [4], and Glen et al., [7]) for a number of reasons.

links.abstract: Our new method uses order statistics to judge the fit of a distribution to data. A test-statistic based on quantiles of order-statistics compares favorably with the Kolmogorov-Smirnov (K-S) and Anderson-Darling (A-D) test statistics. The performance of this new goodness-of-fit test statistic is examined with simulation experiments. For certain hypothesis tests, the test statistic is more powerful than the K-S and A-D test statistics. The new test statistic is calculated using a computer algebra ...

context.text: Conducting these operations in either order has been shown to be equivalent (Glen, Barr & Leemis, [6]), but the order proposed in the algorithm is preferred as the conditional order statistics of the uniform distributions are much more tractable than conditional order statistics using the parent distribution \$F\$.

references.text: A. Glen, D. Barr, L. Leemis, "Order statistics in goodness of fit testing", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 50, no. 2, pp. 209-213, 2001.

context.text: Michael & Schucany [11] present a transformation that transforms censored data into ordered uniform data.

We also rely on previous power studies by Stephens [16], and Michael & Schucany [11] that establish the A–D statistic as generally more powerful than other statistics in testing for uniformity, especially when detecting a shift in \$\mu\$.

references.text: J. R. Michael, W. R. Schucany, "A new approach to testing goodness of fit for censored samples", Technometrics, vol. 21, no. 4, 1979.

context.text: Nelson in [12], and [13] investigated the idea of “precedence testing” which compares two samples in a non-parametric setting to determine which sample appears to be preferred, and can give early indications of the outcome.

references.title: Precedence life test
references.text: L. S. Nelson, "Precedence life test", Technometrics, vol. 5, pp. 491-499, 1963.

context.text: Nelson in [12], and [13] investigated the idea of “precedence testing” which compares two samples in a non-parametric setting to determine which sample appears to be preferred, and can give early indications of the outcome.

Tests on early failures-the
precedence life test
references.text: L. S. Nelson, "Tests on early failures-the precedence life test", Journal of Quality Technology, vol. 25, no. 2, pp. 140-143, 1993.

context.text: O'Reilly & Stephens [14] use a Rosenblatt transform, then invert that transformed data to test ordered uniform data (we will create un-ordered uniform data).

references.title:
Transforming censored samples
for testing fit
references.text: F. J. O'Reilly, M. A. Stephens, "Transforming censored samples for testing fit", Technometrics, vol. 30, no. 1, 1988.

context.text: Rosenblatt [15] presents theory that transforms joint conditional random variables to ordered, uniformly distributed random variables for the censored case (we will instead transform censored data to a complete un-ordered set of i.i.d. uniform data).

Because each of the conditional distributions can be computed, conducting separate PITs on each data value, \$F_{X_{(i)}\vert X_{(i-1)}}(x_{(i)})\$, \$i=2,3,\ldots,r\$ will produce a sample of \$r\$ i.i.d. \$U(0,1)\$ random variates, see Rosenblatt [15], pg. 470, to which any uniformity test can be applied.

references.title: Remarks on a multivariate transformation
references.text: M. Rosenblatt, "Remarks on a multivariate transformation", Annals of Mathematical Statistics, vol. 23, no. 3, 1952.

context.text: They, as well as Stephens [16], point out that the A–D statistic is generally more powerful than the other well-known goodness-of-fit statistics in the case when the mean has shifted.

We also rely on previous power studies by Stephens [16], and Michael & Schucany [11] that establish the A–D statistic as generally more powerful than other statistics in testing for uniformity, especially when detecting a shift in \$\mu\$.

references.title:
EDF statistics for goodness
of fit and some comparisons
references.text: M. A. Stephens, "EDF statistics for goodness of fit and some comparisons", Journal of the American Statistical Association, vol. 69, no. 347, 1974.

references.title: Method of determining whether an improved item has a better mean lifetime than an existing item,
references.text: A. G. Glen, B. L. Foote, Method of determining whether an improved item has a better mean lifetime than an existing item, March 2006.

links.abstract: When the distribution of lifetimes is 2-parameter exponential, Balasooriya (1995) provided a failure-censored reliability sampling plan to save test time. This paper extends the Balasooriya sampling plan to the Weibull distribution and provides a limited failure-censored reliability sampling plan (LFCR) to do life testing when test facilities are scarce. The s-expected test time of the LFCR is computed, and the optimal stopping rule of LFCR corresponding to the shortest test time is established....

context.text: Recently, Wu, Tsai, & Ouyang [18] extended the research of Balasooriya [1] to obtain statistical inference from censored samples.

references.title:
Limited failure-censored life test for the
Weibull distribution
references.text: J.-W. Wu, T. Tsai, L. Ouyang, "Limited failure-censored life test for the Weibull distribution", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 50, no. 1, pp. 107-111, 2001.
